title: Gin
liquorname: Bainbridge Heritage Organic Doug Fir Gin
liquornotes: A wheat gin that includes the most Northwest botanical of them all: freshly harvested Douglas fir boughs from the northeastern corner of the state, which tint the liquor a pale green. But, counterintuitively, the spirit only hints of pine and tastes more sweetly of licorice root and fennel.

title: Gin
liquornotes: This American-style gin reins in the juniper with some charming vegetal and herbal complements. Eight botanicals – including cucumbers from Pike Place Market and lavender from Sequim – are steeped in Batch 206's vodka base, before the spirit is redistilled into gin. Its more far-flung flavors include tarragon and verbena from Provence, juniper berries from Albania and orange peel from Seville.

title: Gin
liquornotes: A bright, citrusy gin that's versatile enough to go neat or mixed, and as sippable as a 92-proof gin can be. This Everett distillery uses only organic ingredients, bottles in American-made glass and donates 1 percent of its sales to sustainability nonprofits. Your hangover never felt this good.
notes: citrus forward, classic london-dry gin. brightness. artisanal methods.
_cvlqs: Favorite cocktail: Thyme bandit from website
_cx0b9: winter tonic: half of a ruby red grapefruit, splash of kina tonic, seltzer water (orange san pellegrino) - just to taste. 1.5 oz halcyon, 3/4 oz. kina, juice of half grapefruit, top with soda.

title: Gin
liquornotes: Big Gin won us over with its straight-shooter MO: an old-world gin that balances fruit and spice with juniper, citrus and Tasmanian pepperberry. Try adding water to turn this gin a pearlescent blue for a fun (but useless) party trick.

title: Gin
liquornotes: A gin for the juniper enthusiast. Creamy, peppery The gin is You'll be looking in your glass for the Christmas tree.
notes: turf cocktail, last word, negroni
_cx0b9: we do tours fridays through sundays, about an hour long. always lead by owners or distillers. $8/person.

title: Gin
liquornotes: Described as "a gin for gin lovers instead of vodka lovers or whisky lovers," Voyager has nevertheless been known to persuade the non-gin-crazed to its ranks. In 2008, owner and master distiller Marc Bernhard created 27 microbatches from the memory of a century-old bottle of English gin he had tasted a few years earlier. A blind taste test of the seven best batches led him to his winning recipe: a clean, juniper-forward gin with what Bernhard describes as a faint "graham cracker taste" from coriander and angelica.
notes: $24.95 at Total Wine (before tax), maybe $27/28 at other places.

title: Gin
liquornotes: Infused with island-sourced and foraged botanicals – including wild roses, blackberries and Madrone barks – this gin sips like a windswept breeze of sea and forest. Of the two versions of this gin, one made with a grain-based spirit and the other distilled from local apple cider, the grain gin was far more popular among our tasters, but it's worth a trek to San Juan Island to test them for yourself. The distillery also makes seasonal iterations featuring nettles, thimbleberries or whatever else is in full bloom that month.
base: grain (Spy Hop) or Washington apples (Spy Hop Harvest Select)
notes: Available at Wine World and Total Wine. Limited availability of items in Capco in West Seattle.
_cx0b9: Seaside: Our new gin honors the coast Salish, roasted camas root, wild poppies from the island, sea pinks (flowers along the shore), sea beans/asparagus. garnish with pickled kelp. working on a vermouth, making in conjunction with san juan island vintners. 51% apple alcohol, 49% grain spirit.

title: Gin
liquornotes: San Juan Island Distillery's new gin honors the Coast Salish people with its native coastal botanicals: roasted camas root, wild California poppies, sea pinks (a shore flower) and naturally briny sea beans, which lend the liquor its alluring salty taste. Allegedly, a garnish of pickled kelp is delightful, but we can vouch for it as a good martini even without the top-shelf seaweed.

title: Gin
liquornotes: Viscous and honey in hue, this Old Tom should intrigue both the gin connosieur and the gin averse. Old Tom gins are experiencing a modern-day renaissance after falling out of favor around the time of Prohibition. They're typically sweeter (sugar might be added post-distillation), mellower and sometimes barrel-aged; this particular Old Tom gains its pleasant vanilla overtones and golden color after resting a month with charred oak chips.
notes: Sweet on the finish, but not too sweet. Pleasant. Don't get super heavy charred oak chips

title: Gin
liquornotes: A mild-mannered, London dry-style gin with one particularly whimsical botanical: the rind of Washington-grown cannonball watermelons. Style point for its clever bottle spout. For a steelier gin, try Sun Liquor's navy strength Gun Club gin (100 proof).

title: Gin
liquornotes: A gateway gin for those just getting their toes wet. It's assertively floral, from the botanical inclusion of lavendar, rosehips, dandelion and chamomile, much of it from the owners' garden in Walla Walla.

title: Vodka
notes: From distillery website: With the sweetness of an orange, and the bitterness of a grapefruit, this vodka bursts on the palate. Refreshingly clean, with slight undertones of spice. It is sweet, but not overly.

title: Vodka
liquornotes: Polish family, so they know their vodka. Distilled from Washington grown corn & barley. Copper stills

title: Vodka
liquornotes: Made from Washington wheat and Mt Rainier spring water

title: Vodka
liquornotes: Triple distilled from grapes. Some awards, specifically calls out locally sourced ingredients. Good serving suggestions

title: Vodka
liquornotes: Mount Rainier water, distilled 6 times, Wine enthusiast rating 88

title: Vodka
liquornotes: 100% Palouse Malted Barley, hit of vanilla sweetness

title: Vodka
liquornotes: Distilled from Washington wildflower honey. Definitely different. Award winning

title: Whiskey
notes: Claims to be first Seattle bourbon made with 100% local grains (95% Washington, 5% Oregon grain)
_cvlqs: From distillery website: Bourbon is the heart and soul of America. 2bar Bourbon is the first Seattle Bourbon to be 100% handmade from all local grains. The sweet butterscotch and vanilla on the front leads to an amazing honey like finish.

title: Whiskey
notes: Tan says it's too young, but idk. Spicy. Paige is not a fan
_cvlqs: From distillery website: Amber in color, this spirit is complex and compelling—with a bit of the unexpected. The nose is immediately greeted with a warm smokiness. This flavor surprises and lingers from start to finish, without overpowering the palate. Loosely based off of George Washington’s original Rye Whiskey, our blend is a classic with a twist.

title: Whiskey
notes: 101 proof Bourbon. Harsh burn on the way down. "Tastes like it smells when people smoke crack". Icky after taste

title: Whiskey
notes: It's alright. Katrina's not a fan. I prefer this to rye though

title: Whiskey
notes: Goes down easy, young. Really dry. Manny thinks it's less harsh than the 3 howls, but not sure. It still seems harsh
_cvlqs: Rye grown in Oregon and Washington. (They have their common whiskey, but uses imported Canadian grains.)

title: Whiskey
notes: Sweet on the tongue. Then has a funny taste. Kinda jumpy and gross.
_cvlqs: Site has tasting notes, but not much else in detail

title: Whiskey
notes: Very light; Seems like the flavor is first and the burn is second in not that great a way. Light in color, light in flavor.
_cvlqs: Silver medal from San Francisco competition. They only make bourbon

title: Whiskey
notes: Also a single malt. Super gross, sweet, and weirdly fruity. Tastes like strawberry Pop Tarts.
_cvlqs: Single malt whiskey: Wildflower honey gives it a little sweetness. Barley from Polouse valley in state

title: Whiskey
notes: Claim to be the largest producer of single malt in America. Has depth, tastes very smooth. Aged in new American oak barrels. FAVORITE
_cvlqs: Seems like their best product, known entity to Tan

title: Whiskey
notes: Aged in an un-used or "virgin" american white oak barrel. Is supposed to have a distinct flavor from whiskeys aged in older barrels. Barley, wheat, malted rye
_cvlqs: Not as good as Westland, but better than the other single malts. Not bad, more flavorful.

title: Whiskey
notes: Katrina: "It just tastes like a bourbon."

title: Whiskey
notes: Tan knows the secret: They started aging it before it was legal. Lighter on the tongue. More full-bodied. Sort of a honey taste FAVORITE
_cvlqs: From distillery website: This medium to full bodied bourbon presents a classic profile of vanilla, caramel and cherry on the nose - rich and compelling. Sweet, smooth corn combined with brown sugar/maple syrup and oak is balanced with a notable spice contributed by the higher than normal rye content. The finish is beautifully long with notes of buttery oak, toffee, and again the cherries make an appearance.

title: Whiskey
notes: Inoffensive, goes down easy, Brian: "Not particularly adroit. haha" Clean.

title: Whiskey
notes: Gross. Tastes like raisins
